response.message: Fantastic questions, it even knocked out a question I was about to record. Keep up the good podcasts.

@11:30 (Joel): "A programming language can't function without ambiguity."

Am I missing something or was this just a speako between "with" and "without"?

@Jon

From the context I thought Joel meant to say: "A natural language can't function without ambiguity."

@Tom: It could be either way. I'm pretty sure there's a mistake somewhere, but it could be the subject (programming language vs non-programming language) the preposition (with vs without) or the object (ambiguity vs non-ambiguity).

The mistake is ambiguous :)
Nice job comparing Silverlight with Flash, typical Microsoft bias. You forgot to mention this little thing called Flex. When you compare two technologies, try comparing apples to apples.
@Joel: those Romanian kids that work for $5/hour really kick @##, don't they? Do you know how many Romanians work at Microsoft?

>> “What’s the most number of questions asked by an actual Stack Overflow user?”

I have been always curious about that myself. As someone who has earned a lot of their rep by asking questions, I've been curious where I ranked. Perhaps if leader boards were implemented for things like "most questions asked" or "most answered given" then that would give us users more stats to obsessive over.
As always... That was a great podcast.  With each one, I take away something new and I get an idea confirmed.
Was a great podcast, was glad to be a part of it and got to ask a question.  Do it again at PDC09!
I think Joel should have skipped the triple shot espresso before recording.  But it did spice it up a bit.

I think what Javascript and PHP have in common that could have made them the most popular languages of the web is that they're free and open (no lock-ins), easy to start doing simple stuff in (gentle learning curve), and are available everywhere (easy deployment).

FYI, Vala is a programming language developed by the GNOME desktop enviroment folks. It compiles a high level language with very good support for GTK libraries into C.

http://live.gnome.org/Vala

Pertaining to question number 7 about unstructured data, I found it intriguing the way FriendFeed stores their data and adds new data to existing records. They simply create a new table for the new bit of data associated with the "parent" record, and utilize indices on the new table for search.

http://bret.appspot.com/entry/how-friendfeed-uses-mysql

Here is their part of the keynote, if you don't want to seek in the other video or install silverlight:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=unq276YCPjE
